AutoDelete Database#

The AutoDelete Database is a specialized component within ManagerX that focuses on managing the automatic deletion of messages and data based on predefined rules and conditions. This feature is essential for maintaining a clean and organized server environment, ensuring that outdated or unnecessary information does not clutter channels.

class DevTools.backend.database.autodelete_db.AutoDeleteDB(db_file='data/autodelete.db')[source]#

Bases: object

Database manager for AutoDelete functionality in Discord channels.

Manages AutoDelete configurations, whitelists, schedules, and statistics for automatic message deletion in Discord channels.

Parameters:

db_file (str, optional) – Path to the SQLite database file (default: “data/autodelete.db”)

db_file#

Path to the database file

Type:

str

conn#

Active database connection

Type:

sqlite3.Connection

cursor#

Database cursor for operations

Type:

sqlite3.Cursor

Examples

>>> db = AutoDeleteDB("my_database.db")
>>> db.add_autodelete(channel_id=123456, duration=3600)
>>> db.close()

Or using context manager: >>> with AutoDeleteDB() as db: … db.add_autodelete(channel_id=123456, duration=3600)

add_autodelete(channel_id, duration, exclude_pinned=True, exclude_bots=False)[source]#

Add or update AutoDelete configuration for a channel.

Parameters:

  • channel_id (int) – Discord channel ID

  • duration (int) – Time in seconds before messages are deleted

  • exclude_pinned (bool, optional) – Whether to exclude pinned messages from deletion (default: True)

  • exclude_bots (bool, optional) – Whether to exclude bot messages from deletion (default: False)

Notes

If a configuration for the channel already exists, it will be updated. Automatically creates a statistics entry if one doesn’t exist.

Examples

>>> db.add_autodelete(channel_id=123456, duration=3600)
>>> db.add_autodelete(channel_id=789012, duration=7200, exclude_bots=True)
add_schedule(channel_id, start_time, end_time, days)[source]#

Add a time schedule for AutoDelete.

Parameters:

  • channel_id (int) – Discord channel ID

  • start_time (str) – Start time in HH:MM format

  • end_time (str) – End time in HH:MM format

  • days (str) – Days when schedule is active (e.g., “Mon,Tue,Wed”)

Notes

Schedules allow AutoDelete to only run during specific time windows.

Examples

>>> db.add_schedule(channel_id=123456, start_time="09:00",
...                 end_time="17:00", days="Mon,Tue,Wed,Thu,Fri")
add_to_whitelist(channel_id, target_id, target_type)[source]#

Add an entry to the whitelist.

Parameters:

  • channel_id (int) – Discord channel ID

  • target_id (int) – Discord role ID or user ID

  • target_type ({'role', 'user'}) – Type of the whitelist target

Raises:

ValueError – If target_type is not ‘role’ or ‘user’

Notes

Whitelisted roles/users will not have their messages auto-deleted. Duplicate entries are silently ignored.

Examples

>>> db.add_to_whitelist(channel_id=123456, target_id=789012, target_type='role')
>>> db.add_to_whitelist(channel_id=123456, target_id=345678, target_type='user')
cleanup_orphaned_data()[source]#

Remove orphaned data from auxiliary tables.

Returns:

Number of orphaned records removed

Return type:

int

Notes

Removes whitelist entries, schedules, and statistics that reference non-existent AutoDelete configurations.

Examples

>>> removed = db.cleanup_orphaned_data()
>>> print(f"Removed {removed} orphaned records")
clear_whitelist(channel_id)[source]#

Clear complete whitelist for a channel.

Parameters:

channel_id (int) – Discord channel ID

Examples

>>> db.clear_whitelist(123456)
close()[source]#

Close the database connection.

Notes

Should be called when done using the database to free resources. Not needed when using the context manager syntax.

Examples

>>> db = AutoDeleteDB()
>>> # ... use database ...
>>> db.close()
export_all_settings()[source]#

Export all AutoDelete settings.

Returns:

Dictionary containing all configurations, whitelists, schedules, and stats

Return type:

dict

Notes

The returned dictionary can be serialized to JSON and later imported using import_settings().

Examples

>>> data = db.export_all_settings()
>>> import json
>>> with open('backup.json', 'w') as f:
...     json.dump(data, f, indent=2)
get_all()[source]#

Get all AutoDelete configurations.

Returns:

List of tuples containing (channel_id, duration, exclude_pinned, exclude_bots) sorted by channel_id

Return type:

list of tuple

Examples

>>> configs = db.get_all()
>>> for channel_id, duration, exclude_pinned, exclude_bots in configs:
...     print(f"Channel {channel_id}: {duration}s")
get_autodelete(channel_id)[source]#

Get AutoDelete duration for a channel.

Parameters:

channel_id (int) – Discord channel ID

Returns:

Duration in seconds, or None if no configuration exists

Return type:

int or None

Notes

This method is for backward compatibility. Use get_autodelete_full() for complete configuration details.

Examples

>>> duration = db.get_autodelete(123456)
>>> if duration:
...     print(f"Messages deleted after {duration} seconds")
get_autodelete_full(channel_id)[source]#

Get complete AutoDelete configuration for a channel.

Parameters:

channel_id (int) – Discord channel ID

Returns:

Tuple of (duration, exclude_pinned, exclude_bots) or None if not found

Return type:

tuple or None

Examples

>>> config = db.get_autodelete_full(123456)
>>> if config:
...     duration, exclude_pinned, exclude_bots = config
...     print(f"Duration: {duration}s, Exclude pinned: {exclude_pinned}")
get_database_info()[source]#

Get database information and statistics.

Returns:

Dictionary containing record counts for each table and file size information

Return type:

dict

Examples

>>> info = db.get_database_info()
>>> print(f"Database size: {info['file_size_mb']} MB")
>>> print(f"AutoDelete configs: {info['autodelete_count']}")
get_global_stats()[source]#

Get global statistics across all channels.

Returns:

Dictionary containing global statistics or None if no data exists. Keys: ‘active_channels’, ‘total_deleted’, ‘total_errors’, ‘latest_deletion’

Return type:

dict or None

Examples

>>> stats = db.get_global_stats()
>>> if stats:
...     print(f"Active channels: {stats['active_channels']}")
...     print(f"Total deleted: {stats['total_deleted']}")
get_schedules(channel_id)[source]#

Get all schedules for a channel.

Parameters:

channel_id (int) – Discord channel ID

Returns:

List of tuples containing (start_time, end_time, days) sorted by start_time

Return type:

list of tuple

Examples

>>> schedules = db.get_schedules(123456)
>>> for start, end, days in schedules:
...     print(f"{start}-{end} on {days}")
get_stats(channel_id)[source]#

Get statistics for a channel.

Parameters:

channel_id (int) – Discord channel ID

Returns:

Dictionary containing statistics or None if not found. Keys: ‘deleted_count’, ‘error_count’, ‘last_deletion’,

’created_at’, ‘updated_at’

Return type:

dict or None

Examples

>>> stats = db.get_stats(123456)
>>> if stats:
...     print(f"Deleted: {stats['deleted_count']} messages")
...     print(f"Errors: {stats['error_count']}")
get_whitelist(channel_id)[source]#

Get whitelist for a channel.

Parameters:

channel_id (int) – Discord channel ID

Returns:

Dictionary with ‘roles’ and ‘users’ keys, each containing a list of IDs

Return type:

dict

Examples

>>> whitelist = db.get_whitelist(123456)
>>> print(f"Whitelisted roles: {whitelist['roles']}")
>>> print(f"Whitelisted users: {whitelist['users']}")
import_settings(data, overwrite=False)[source]#

Import AutoDelete settings.

Parameters:

  • data (dict) – Dictionary containing exported settings (from export_all_settings())

  • overwrite (bool, optional) – Whether to overwrite existing configurations (default: False)

Returns:

Dictionary with ‘imported’ and ‘skipped’ counts

Return type:

dict

Notes

If overwrite is False, existing channel configurations are skipped. If overwrite is True, existing configurations are replaced.

Examples

>>> import json
>>> with open('backup.json', 'r') as f:
...     data = json.load(f)
>>> result = db.import_settings(data, overwrite=True)
>>> print(f"Imported: {result['imported']}, Skipped: {result['skipped']}")
remove_autodelete(channel_id)[source]#

Remove AutoDelete configuration and all associated data.

Parameters:

channel_id (int) – Discord channel ID

Notes

This cascades to delete all associated whitelist entries, schedules, and statistics for the channel due to foreign key constraints.

Examples

>>> db.remove_autodelete(123456)
remove_from_whitelist(channel_id, target_id, target_type)[source]#

Remove an entry from the whitelist.

Parameters:

  • channel_id (int) – Discord channel ID

  • target_id (int) – Discord role ID or user ID

  • target_type ({'role', 'user'}) – Type of the whitelist target

Examples

>>> db.remove_from_whitelist(channel_id=123456, target_id=789012, target_type='role')
remove_schedule(channel_id, start_time=None)[source]#

Remove schedule(s) for a channel.

Parameters:

  • channel_id (int) – Discord channel ID

  • start_time (str, optional) – Specific start time to remove. If None, removes all schedules

Examples

>>> db.remove_schedule(channel_id=123456, start_time="09:00")
>>> db.remove_schedule(channel_id=123456)  # Remove all schedules
reset_stats(channel_id)[source]#

Reset statistics for a channel.

Parameters:

channel_id (int) – Discord channel ID

Notes

Sets deleted_count and error_count to 0, clears last_deletion timestamp.

Examples

>>> db.reset_stats(123456)
update_stats(channel_id, deleted_count=0, error_count=0)[source]#

Update statistics for a channel.

Parameters:

  • channel_id (int) – Discord channel ID

  • deleted_count (int, optional) – Number of messages deleted (default: 0)

  • error_count (int, optional) – Number of errors encountered (default: 0)

Notes

Counts are cumulative. The last_deletion timestamp is only updated if deleted_count > 0.

Examples

>>> db.update_stats(channel_id=123456, deleted_count=10)
>>> db.update_stats(channel_id=123456, error_count=1)
vacuum_database()[source]#

Optimize the database.

Notes

Rebuilds the database file, repacking it into a minimal amount of disk space. This can improve performance but may take time on large databases.

Examples

>>> db.vacuum_database()
